ok let's look at a different area let's look at databases it's becoming more and

almost always when we talk to companies the reason they want to move to the
cloud is the agility that it affords them that's why customers of all sizes across all
industries are migrating their applications to AWS in a big way now
let's look at how the breadth and depth of AWS helps with migration we've

no one-size-fits-all approach if you want to move as fast as possible to the cloud you need the broadest and deepest
set of tools one of the first things you're gonna look to migrate is your
data and as I mentioned earlier we have 11 unique ways to move data into and out
of AWS let me highlight a couple first there's AWS snowball it's a petabyte
scale data transfer appliance that's designed to be secure and help you transfer large amounts of data to the
cloud transferring data with snowball is simple fast more secure and can be up to
90% cheaper than using the internet or if you want to transfer more data we
offer AWS snowmobile the first exabytes scale data transfer device now
snowmobile is actually a truck that you drive up your database enter connect to
your backbone network and store up to a 100 petabytes of storage then we drive it to AWS and upload the data for you or
AWS data sync which is a data transfer service that automates transferring and
synchronizing data over the network it's a lot like our sync but faster an AWS
Storage Gateway which helps you easily connect on-premise applications to AWS data services now we'll talk about this
a bit later but one of the fundamental building blocks to any application is the database and we have tools to make
it easy to migrate these as well the AWS data migrations database migrations
service allows you to migrate your data to AWS and it's important to note that
it works in both directions you can migrate in and you can migrate out more than 140,000 databases have been
migrated using the AWS database migration service when we think about enabling application

Windows Server instances running on AWS
we've been talking about migration but many of you might be wondering what about hybrid well we believe in the
fullness of time the vast majority of companies will run all of their workloads in the cloud it's a priority
for us to make it easy for customers to run AWS as a seamless extension of their
existing infrastructure this is something that customers like to call hybrid IT architectures and if you think
about it pretty much any enterprise customer running on AWS today who's not
all-in is running a hybrid IT architecture and we see our role in hybrid as working with our customers to
allow them to seamlessly extend their on-premise infrastructure to AWS by
working closely with enterprises AWS has developed the industry's broadest set of hybrid capabilities including storage
networking security deployment management to make it easy for you to integrate with the cloud as a seamless
extension of your data center for example AWS Direct Connect lets you easily and reliably connect your data
center network to AWS over private activity AWS outpost a recently
announced service that will be released later this year provides the same AWC
services infrastructure and operating models but allows you to run it anywhere any data center any colocation facility
any factory outposts are perfect for certain really low latency use cases
where you need to be able to run but you want to seamlessly integrate with your AWS environment snowball edge is great
when you need to run compute at the edge in a place where maybe you don't have consistent network access or where you
might need a ruggedized container for that compute and finally VMware cloud on AWS allows you to use the software that
you've been using on-premise directly on the AWS platform we've seen a lot of
momentum with AWS cloud on AWS and it's why we've worked so closely with VMware on our unique partnership with the
launch of VMware cloud on AWS customers have the ability to run the same VMware software and tools they've been using
for years on Prem but to use it directly on AWS so we have many many customers migrating
to the platform and operating in a hybrid mode as they transition using AWS as depth and breadth but what about
those building entirely new applications well we have a ton of customers who have started with AWS on day one let's look
at how some of these customers are building and running their applications using AWS ok let's take a look first at
how things existed before AWS you used to have to build big monolithic software
architectures with all of your processes tightly coupled in the same application this is how we built things when I
joined Amazon if you can believe it we only had a few dozen software engineers back then and we all collaborated on
this one big piece of code called obidos now obidos was an amazing piece of software depending on how you used it
you could run the website you could run the customer service center you could run the fulfillment centers really
obidos could do almost anything but it had one big problem and that is it didn't scale as our software teams
grew into the hundreds we were constantly struggling to make changes either we were breaking the build or we
were simply struggling to make changes to this large monolithic codebase and what we learned is that monolithic
software doesn't scale and so we started building services and so in a
microservices architecture an application is built as an independent set of components where each application
does something and does it very well and you can iterate on each of those micro services to deliver at whatever pace of
innovation that piece of your system requires and in Amazon we discovered by factoring obidos into all these services
we could move much more quickly and scale much more efficiently so we started building services for everything
we had a service to manage customer information a service for personalization a service for community
features a service for order processing pretty soon we had hundreds of services and things improved dramatically and
this was a pretty big innovative idea back then believe it or not but today it's the cost of being in business
because micro services are independently run each service can be updated deployed
and scaled to meet the demands of that portion of the application and you can structure teams around these micro
services and that allows those teams to have the knowledge and authority to make changes that they need quickly and this
allows you to move very quickly as a business so as we look at this
transition from monolithic software to microservices an obvious place to start is compute and commute compute has been
changing over time when we launched ec2 in 2006 it was all about instances and
today we have dozens of different kinds of instances to meet whatever type of
workloads you might have then came the rise of containers then the rise of lambda event based
processing today most of our customers find that some combination of these services makes the most sense for their
Apple patience so let's start by looking at instances AWS has over 200 instance
types to allow you to perfectly match the requirements of your application to your hardware we've got general purpose
instances as well as instances tailored for HPC or Big Data we've got the most
powerful machine learning and GPU instances in the p3 and the p3 DN we've
also got a broad choice of processors whether Intel or AMD for x86 or the
recently announced graviton ARM based processor which can allow you to save up to 45% on scale out workloads in the
past year we've added a lot of new capabilities as well you can have bare metal you can have directed patched SSD
or you can have enhanced networking and we have the ability to elastically add resources to instance types so you can
customize them as you wish you can add things like elastic graphics elastic storage or elastic inference now let's
talk about containers Amazon elastic container service is a highly scalable high-performance container management
service that supports docker containers and it allows you to easily run applications on a managed cluster of ec2
instances with ECS you don't actually have to deal with any of the container automation and orchestration software or
manage any of the virtual machine cluster underneath it that's all managed for you and it's designed from the
ground up to work with the rest of the AWS services and we've taken this one
step further with AWS Fargate AWS Fargate is a compute engine for AWS ECS
that completely removes the need to know about the instances at all with faregates you only focus on your
application you can launch and scale quickly and easily and you pay only based on the actual usage so you don't
pay for the size of your cluster this allows you to spend more time innovating
and building and less time managing servers and dealing with IT AWS Fargate runs tens of millions of
customer containers each week ok
if you're more of a kubernetes fan last year we launched Amazon eks a managed
secure service that allows you to easily run kubernetes but without the hassle of having to build manage and maintain your
kubernetes control plan yourself eks is also tightly integrated with AWS allowing you making it the best place to
run kubernetes and we're not doing this alone we're coordinating with the
kubernetes community and working with them to make AWS the best place to run kubernetes and eks is certified
kubernetes ensuring compatibility with your existing applications in fact any major change that we make to kubernetes
we upstream to the kubernetes community first before we adopted any KS and a lot
of customers are doing amazing things with containers and production get carbon is a Nigerian FinTech company

its software development process by using Amazon ECS to manage its 100-plus
containers Carbon has reduced the average application deployment time from 3 days to less than 30 minutes finally
let's look at that bass driven service computing which we pioneered with lambda
lambda lets you run code without provisioning or managing instances or servers at all you can run code for
virtually any type of application or back-end service with zero administration and very high uptime but
it's not just lambda to build truly service applications you need support for service computing from a broad range
of services and lambda integrates with 47 AWS services which is several times
more than any other provider and you'll see monitoring and logging up there you'll notice identity you'll see
communication it's not just functions it's not just managed services it's a
complete service application platform and it's this breadth and depth of the

your business into your customer and not IT management or infrastructure customers like impression a paperless

customers use service computing the company's entire infrastructure runs on
AWS lambda and service is happening everywhere and it's happening at scale

importance of having the right tool and that's true with databases as well but
it's also important to be free of abusive relationships from your tool providers if you look at Oracle and
Microsoft they're expensive they have high lock-in and they're not
particularly customer focused when they're not looking for ways to audit
you and find you in non-compliance they might be making erratic decisions overnight which seem to benefit them and
maybe not so much you and people are sick of it it's hard to build a business
because the databases are so central to your application that when your tools
provider seems to be constantly prioritizing their own needs over your needs it's difficult
and this is the reason why so many customers seem to be moving as fast as they can away from the old guard
databases and to the open source databases like my sequel Postgres SQL
and Maria DB but many of these customers want the openness and customer friendly
policies of open source databases with the performance of the old guard databases and that's why we built Amazon
aurora amazon aurora is a fully my sequel and Postgres sequel compatible
database that combines the performance and availability of high-end commercial databases with the simplicity openness
and cost-effectiveness of an open source database and because it's fully Postgres
in my sequel compatible you can easily migrate to Aurora using the standard my
sequel and Postgres sequel import/export tools or imported directly from your snapshot it also means that the code
applications tools and drivers that you already have will work with Amazon Aurora with little or no change but it
isn't just a managed database Aurora is several times faster than your typical my sequel or Postgres sequel database so
you can easily scale your database up or down depending on that your applications needs and it's at least as durable and
highly available as the old guard with four nines of availability it has full tolerant and self-healing storage built
for the cloud and it's continuously backing your data up to Amazon s3 you can also backtrack to a point in
time recovery to within seconds to recover from user error or logical corruption and it provides all of this
at one-tenth the cost of a commercial database so Amazon Aurora is still the
fastest growing service in all of AWS history and part of the reason it continues to grow so quickly is the pace
of innovation we've launched thirty-five significant features on Aurora in just
this last year alone and that's part of why we're seeing customers flocked to Aurora Cape Town based mix telematics is a
global leader in fleet and mobile asset management solutions the company uses Amazon Arora to manage 70 terabytes of
assets and event data by migrating from Microsoft sequel to Amazon Aurora mix
